item.title: Richard Li’s FWD Rises in HK Debut, Reversing Earlier Decline
item.description: Billionaire Richard Li’s FWD Group Holdings Ltd. rose in its Hong Kong trading debut, reversing earlier declines, after an initial public offering that raised HK$3.5 billion ($442 million).
item.dc:creator: Sangmi Cha

media:content.media:description: Richard Li Photographer: Chan Long Hei/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Threatens 10% Tariff on BRICS-Aligned Nation
item.description: President Trump has said he would put an additional 10% tariff on any country aligning themselves with "the Anti-American policies of BRICS." Speaking to Bloomberg's Insight with Haslinda Amin, Indian School of Business Professor Nirmalya Kumar says countries should wait and watch to see if the President's latest threat will actually materialize. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Fall, Dollar Gains as Trade Worries Return: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks declined and the dollar gained in a risk-averse start to the week, as President Donald Trump dialed up trade tensions saying the US will start issuing tariff letters to countries as soon as Monday.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

media:content.media:description: The logo for Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) displayed on a screen at the Exchange Square complex in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, Feb. 26, 2025. Hong Kong's stock exchange reported its highest quarterly profit in nearly four years after China's stimulus measures boosted trading and listing volume.

item.title: BNP Paribas AM: Positive on EM Local Currency Bonds
item.description: Alaa Bushehri, head of Emerging Market Debt at BNP Paribas Asset Management, says she finds attractive valuations in local currency debt in India and Indonesia. She also sees similar opportunities in a number of Latin American, jurisdictions including Brazil and Mexico. She discusses the market outlook with David Ingles and Yvonne Man on "Bloomberg: The China Show." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Is the Dollar Resting, or Nailed to Its Perch?
item.description: Tariff uncertainty must end to determine whether there’s still life in the old bird.
item.dc:creator: John Authers, Richard Abbey

media:content.media:description: Michael Palin and John Cleese of comedy team Monty Python perform the 'Dead Parrot Sketch' on stage in London, 1974. (Photo by Michael Putland/Getty Images) Photographer: Michael Putland/Hulton Archive

item.title: Oil Prices Now Aligning More With Fundamentals, Lombard Odier's Woods Says
item.description: Oil prices declined after OPEC+ agreed to a bigger-than-expected production increase next month. Lombard Odier Asia CIO John Woods shares his views on the energy markets, telling Bloomberg Television that "oil is now aligning more with fundamentals than any geopolitical premium that might have been built in." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nissan to Sell ¥150 Billion Convertible Bonds For Recovery
item.description: Nissan Motor Co. plans to sell ¥150 billion ($1.04 billion) of convertible bonds to help fund new chief executive officer Ivan Espinosa’s turnaround of the ailing automaker.
item.dc:creator: Peter Vercoe, Kana Nishizawa

item.title: Thai Baht’s Surge at Risk From Turmoil, Top Forecaster Says
item.description: The Thai baht’s four-month rally is likely to falter as political turmoil is expected to weigh on the economy, according to the currency’s top forecaster.
item.dc:creator: Rthvika Suvarna, Matthew Burgess

item.title: Banking, Booze and 007’s Wheels: 10 Companies to Watch Right Now
item.description: Analysts at Bloomberg Intelligence have sifted through thousands of publicly traded companies to highlight a select few for investors.
item.dc:creator: Tim Craighead

item.title: What Is American Exceptionalism, and Is It Coming to an End?
item.description: Record US stock prices suggest investors still believe in TINA — the idea that “there is no alternative” to US markets. So why has the dollar been sliding?
item.dc:creator: Michael Msika, Enda Curran

item.title: LG Electronics Misses Estimates on Tariffs, Consumer Sentiment
item.description: LG Electronics Inc. reported preliminary profit that missed estimates, with the consumer electronics maker blaming US tariffs intensifying competition and costs. Shares fell as much as 3.9%.
item.dc:creator: Reina Sasaki

item.title: FWD Eyes China Market After 'Emotional' HK Debut
item.description: Shares in Richard Li's insurer FWD Group were steady on the first day of trading after raising $442 million in its IPO. The company's CEO Hyunh Thanh Phong says Monday's listing was an emotional moment, after several attempts to go public in the US and Hong Kong. With new funding now in place, Hyunh told David Ingles and Yvonne Man on 'Bloomberg: The China Show' that the company plans to break into the Mainland China market. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: The Asia Trade 7/7/25
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Tokyo and Sydney with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Metals Fall as Trump Stirs Trade Uncertainty With BRICS Threat
item.description: Copper and other industrial metals extended losses after US President Donald Trump injected fresh uncertainty into his trade agenda with a pledge to impose a 10% tariff on any country aligned with the BRICS bloc of nations.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie

item.title: Oil Drops as Larger OPEC+ Supply Increase Raises Glut Concerns
item.description: Oil extended declines after OPEC+ agreed to a bigger-than-expected production increase next month, raising concerns about oversupply just as US tariffs fan fears about the demand outlook.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Lua

media:content.media:description: An Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) branded oil drum at the COP29 climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Wednesday, Nov. 13, 2024. The United Nations climate change conference, COP29, runs through Nov. 22.

item.title: Thai Budget Bill, Spending to Move as Planned, Minister Says
item.description: Thailand will push ahead with plans to stimulate the economy and pass the budget for next year as planned, Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira said, easing concerns that an ongoing political crisis could derail economic policy.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

item.title: Gold Edges Lower as Investors Track US Trade Policy and Dollar
item.description: Gold fell as traders sought to track shifts in US trade policy, with bullion edging lower as President Donald Trump signaled an additional 10% tariff would apply to countries aligned with the BRICS group of nations.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

item.title: Kiwi Rally May Lose Steam as Rate Cuts Loom for Sluggish Economy
item.description: The New Zealand dollar’s rally may fade in the second half of the year, as the central bank continues to cut interest rates and the local economy remains sluggish.
item.dc:creator: Michael G Wilson, Matthew Burgess

item.title: Thailand Offers US More Trade Concessions to Avert 36% Levy
item.description: Thailand is making a last-ditch effort to avert a punitive 36% export levy threatened by the Trump administration with offers of greater market access for US farm and industrial goods, along with increased purchases of energy and Boeing jets.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes next to shipping containers at the Bangkok Port in Bangkok, Thailand, Sunday, Jan. 28, 2024. Thailand is scheduled to announce export figures on Jan. 31.

item.title: Germany’s $40 Billion Pension Gives Mandate to China Stock Fund
item.description: A German pension fund has tapped a Chinese firm’s Hong Kong arm to help it invest in local stocks, in a rare move among global allocators that have been cautious about gaining exposure to the nation’s equities.
item.dc:creator: Echo Wong

item.title: Curbs on Jane Street’s India Operations May Deepen Options Slump
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: BRICS Leaders Condemn US, Israel Attacks on Iran
item.description: BRICS leaders have condemned US and Israeli attacks on Iran and called for Israel to withdraw troops from the Gaza Strip. The group released a joint statement on Sunday, the first day of their summit in Brazil. Bloomberg's Flavia Krause-Jackson reports from Rio de Janeiro. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: After Gasoline, China’s Oil Refiners Face a Jet Fuel Glut
item.description: China’s oil refiners are grappling with an oversupply of jet fuel, in yet another blow to the bottom line of a sector already dealing with ebbing demand for gasoline and diesel.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Nicholas Lua

item.title: Uniqlo Owner, Seven & i To Set Tone for Japan’s Consumer Sector
item.description: Uniqlo owner Fast Retailing Co. and Seven & i Holdings Co. will show how Japan’s consumer sector is faring as Asia’s earnings season kicks off.
item.dc:creator: Reina Sasaki, Justina T Lee, Harshita Swaminathan

media:content.media:description: Uniqlo Park in Mitsui Outlet Park Yokohama Bayside in Yokohama. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: US Trading Partners Chase Deals Ahead of Deadline
item.description: Major US trading partners hurried over the weekend to secure deals or lobby for extra time ahead of President Trump's July 9 deadline. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent also indicated that some countries lacking an agreement by Wednesday will have the option of a three-week extension to negotiate. Bloomberg's Stephen Engle reports on the latest. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Taiwan Stock ETFs Lead Inflows in Asia With $19 Billion Haul
item.description: Traders are swarming to equity-focused, exchange-traded funds listed in Taiwan, with demand from retail investors and a strong local currency driving up flows.
item.dc:creator: Cindy Wang, Betty Hou

item.title: Lutnick Says Trump’s Tariffs Will Take Effect on Aug. 1
item.description: President Donald Trump’s country-by-country tariffs will take effect Aug. 1, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said, signaling some breathing room for US trading partners ahead of a July 9 deadline previously set by the president.
item.dc:creator: Tony Czuczka

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick speaks to members of the media before boarding Air Force One with US President Donald Trump at Morristown Municipal Airport in Morristown, New Jersey, on July 6, 2025.

item.title: US, Brazil Try to Seal Tariff Deal Before Trump’s Deadline: Uol
item.description: Representatives from Brazil and the US held a video conference on Friday to discuss a new tariff deal before President Donald Trump’s deadline on Wednesday, local media outlet Uol reported.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Pulice

item.title: Decade-Old Local Currency Push by BRICS Is Still A Pipe Dream
item.description: BRICS countries once again failed to make significant strides in the cross-border payments system for trade and investment they’ve been discussing for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Mirette Magdy
